messages.content: One huge market I'm excited about is portable A/R workstations. Virtual machine run off the cloud, no need for cubicles or monitors. Dual monitors on smart glasses whenever and wherever you set up to work. Will accelerate flexible workstations, boost productivity on the go, and lower costs. Needs to be paired with some sort of keyboard & mouse but theoretically you could have a "touch" keyboard and trackpad shown in A/R as projected on whatever surface you're working on. Might need some sort of wearable on hands or wrists for tactile feedback. I have strong conviction that this will be a big market (though not sure if we will have dedicated work tech, or if it will be the same tech as we use for A/R recreationally -- like we do for our smartphones).

This is really cool. I hadn't really thought about this use. Though, I do think it would be the same technology that we would use recreationally because both markets would demand this. I personally also don't really see new firms coming in to this market because the barrier to entry would be too high. I think it would just be the same firms currently dominating (Apple, Google, Microsoft). Also because people would want to continue using the same operating systems. That's why I think Apple Glass will do really well.
i made a tweet about this a while back, but curious to hear thoughts https://twitter.com/yashgodiwala/status/1336914873582678016

anyone knows the cheapest way to try out vr? is google cardboard any good?

Google cardboard isn't really comparable to a proper VR experience with a good headset, it's almost a night and day difference. Your best bet would be to find someone who already owns one and try to use theirs, or once covid restrictions ease up try to find an arcade with VR headsets for rent.

i own a cardboard and have tried quest (quest 1, planning on getting my hands on quest 2 but dont own either atm) and can confirm it's a night and day difference compared to having actual proper hardware instead of just your phone, 6dof instead of 3dof, actual controllers, etc etc

that said, if you _really_ are reluctant to part with the $300 for a quest 2 or worried about facebook whatevers, or if you just want to try vr one time and have no intentions of picking it up again then a cardboard is fine to dip your toes in
quest 2 is 450€ in europe 😮 I would buy it if I was able to try it in advance, but I never used VR goggles, so 450€ is too much for just wanting to try it out
are there any other viable use cases other than gaming right now?

for vr? off the top of my head VR travelling (doesn't even have to exist on earth!), hanging out with friends, going to concerts, relaxing with beach sounds, 3-D video experiences, creating virtual art (there was a very cool one i've tried where you essentially have a full fledged ms paint-like thing but in 3D)

those are the obvious things that you as an individual can do (so ignoring things that might be useful in an economic sense, like virtual  training for how to repair something, remotely operating some machine with your gestures idk)

learning about outer space or the ocean by actually being "in space" or "in the ocean" and seeing the fish swim around you, literally flying around (not technically a game although i guess it could be part of a game mechanic)

there's this guided walking tech which subtly shifts the camera every time your eyes do saccadic movements so you don't notice it but end up walking in big circles instead of straight lines-- you can simulate a space the size of NYC in a large warehouse, last i heard
even sitting in a chair watching a 3-D rollercoaster vid is a whooooole rush holy cow
teleoperation of robots imo
ok wow that's a lot more than I expected! makes me consider buying the quest 2 haha
does it really feel immersive? like is the simulation good enough (e.g from a graphics perspective) to really make it seem like you're inside the virtual world?

depends on what you mean by immersive! for a regular video game analogy, when we play mario of course it's very clearly not real, and yet it's immersive at the same time. I've done the roller coaster video and literally had to remind myself i was sitting still to not rock back and forth in my chair, tried super hot and had to be careful to keep an open space to not punch anyone, etc etc

i suppose a lot of it will depend on the details of hardware and software-- something that can refresh its screen fast enough will feel better and reduce VR sickness versus something that's less powerful, or a big heavy program vs. a small light one
cool! thanks a lot! will try to get my hands on one
I wonder if the Go can be had cheaply now

I've bought two Go's, the quest 1 and the quest 2. The quest is exponentially better than the Go. Would not recommend the Go. The quest 1 blew my mind the first time I had a friend's on an instantly bought one haha. The quest 2 wasn't much of an upgrade. There needs to be more useful content for it. I think on of the most interesting cases outside of gaming is what Spatial OS is doing rn with their meeting software.

We hosted a few college classes with everyone in a virtual room and the instructor going through slides which was pretty awesome and we're working on wider adoption of it with everyone remote rn. Education will be another big one, but not a solid use case to put it on everyday even with the games available

messages.content: Lol I have like a AR/VR dev gig
how long can you wear those before getting a headache? or is it not a problem anymore (I heard the early ones caused one after a wearing them for too long)
might not be important right now but if we really want to create a metaverse and have people spend long hours inside vr I think eye damage and headaches are huge issues imho

Yeah in development, trying to accommodate for motion sickness and fatigue is a hard. It's why most VR games, you are stationary. As refresh rates get better, this will help. Also, FB is working on a VR headset that physically moves the lens based on where your eye is focusing.
I have the quest 2, no regrets. Threw nextdns on it so it doesn't talk back to zucc 99% of the time.
I use the quest 2 for work with virtual desktop or inmersed vr, cool for editing videos bc you can have timeline/preview spaced out.
Usually after 3ish hours when stationary. But on games maybe after an hour or two.

wait wait nextdns? i just googled it and i'm kinda surprised that something that feels as locked down as vr has this stuff avialable
also how trustworthy is this thing anyways

Ok, so the oculus quest 2 (and OG quest) run Android, yep, AOSP. Then FB adds their stuff on top. Because it runs Android, we can use adb to talk to it, and set parameters, such as which DNS resolver to point to, I set my headset to point at my NextDNS config, which blocks FANG (need Amazon) domains, and that way it won't ping to FB (or any other company I dislike). Since I mostly use it for virtual desktop, beat saber and top golf it doesn't need to ping FB does it? https://twitter.com/konrad_it/status/1339310411485732866

embeds.description: Put nextdns on the quest 2... No regrets.

messages.content: The thing that is extremely worrying with the quest devices is how Facebook has decided to make it compulsory to sync a FB account to the headset, which understandably many people do not like. The quest is also the best wireless headset on the market, and there's no other choice, and the German regulators are kinda pissed at that: https://www.theverge.com/2020/12/10/22167509/germany-fco-investigation-facebook-oculus-account-requirements-competition

embeds.title: German regulators are investigating Facebook for its controversial ...

By that I mean, they put the sensors in a package that actually works really well and give you an SDK to build apps for it but they don't give you access to the raw data coming from the sensors. Hi all, I just launched https://www.unai.one/ It's a VR headset and the virtual world inside, both designed to make being with someone in VR feel the same as in real life

We've built the most popular open source VR headset when we were 15 years old and now (4 years latter) we want to make the Metaverse real!
Oh and we are hiring a lot!

I'm pretty sure this server is full of very talented people, so if you are into moonshot, and interested in the Multiverse and building the hardware and software from scratch you might like to check out our open positions!

embeds.title: Unai - A VR headset designed for real social interactions
embeds.description: Meeting and talking with people is the best experience VR has to offer. Unai is both a headset and a virtual world designed to make that experience a whole better.

I'm the co-founder of Scena 360. My friends and I are making virtual gatherings feel more like in-person gatherings!
